titleStmt.title: Event-Triggered Adaptive Tracking Control for Multiagent Systems With Unknown Disturbances

affiliation.orgName: Key Laboratory of Intelligent Control and Decision of Complex System

analytic.title: Event-Triggered Adaptive Tracking Control for Multiagent Systems With Unknown Disturbances

biblStruct.note: received March 6, 2018; revised June 6, 2018 and August 12, 2018; accepted August 27, 2018.

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: This paper considers the event-triggered tracking control problem of nonlinear multiagent systems with unknown disturbances. The event-triggering mechanism is considered in the controller update, which decreases the amount of communication and reduces the frequency of the controller update in practice. By designing a disturbance observer, the unknown external disturbances are estimated. Moreover, a part of adaptive parameters are only dependent on the number of followers, which weakens the computational burden. It is shown that all the signals are bounded, and the consensus tracking errors are located in a small neighborhood of the origin based on the Lyapunov stability theory and backstepping approach. Finally, the effectiveness of the approach proposed in this paper is proved by simulation results.

case of consensus exists, namely, the leader-following problem. In [8], the leader-following control problem for multiagent systems was addressed by a neural-network-based adaptive approach, where the uncertainty in the agents' dynamics and the time-varying leader's states were both taken into account. Yu et al. [9] studied a distributed linear consensus problem for the second-order multiagent systems by using current and sampled position data. Meng et al. [10] analyzed leaderless and leader-following consensus issues by timedomain and frequency-domain approaches. Cheng et al. [11] investigated the consensus control problem for multiagent systems with measurement noises. Su et al. [12] proposed a connectivity-preserving consensus algorithm for secondorder multiple nonlinear dynamical mobile agents with a virtual leader. Li et al. [13] investigated the consensus control problem for multiagent systems where the leader's input was bounded and unknown. Yu et al. [14] addressed a leaderfollowing control problem for multiagent systems with updated control gains. Li et al. [15] proposed a distributed continuous adaptive method for multiagent systems with a linear dynamic. Su et al. [16] developed a low gain feedback strategy to handle a distributed consensus problem for linear multiagent systems on switching networks. In [17], the leaderfollowing problem was addressed for multiagent systems with mismatched unknown parameters and uncertain external disturbances.

In the classical control framework, the controller usually adopts time-sampling. In the view of analysis and design, the periodic sampling might be preferable. However, this method is inferior to event-sampling from the resources disposition point of view. When the system is working naturally or is not affected by any disturbance, executing the control mission is clearly a waste of communication resources. Hence, more attention have been paid to the event-triggered control of multiagent systems [18]- [20]. Yue et al. [21] proposed a new event-triggered strategy to obtund the communication load in the networked control systems (NCSs). Peng and Yang [18] considered an event-triggered control problem for NCSs with event-triggered communication and H ∞ control codesign. Guo et al. [22] proposed a novel distributed eventtriggered sampled-data transmission protocol for distributed multiagent systems under a directed graph. Garcia et al. [23] proposed a novel consensus event-triggered control strategy to address the consensus problem with general linear dynamics and undirected graphs. In [24], a decentralized 2168-2267 c 2018 IEEE. Personal use is permitted, but republication/redistribution requires IEEE permission.
See http://www.ieee.org/publications_standards/publications/rights/index.html for more information.

event-triggered controller was designed for linear multiagent systems. Zhu et al. [25] studied an event-based consensus problem for second-order discrete-time multiagent systems. Hu et al. [26] developed the event-triggered and self-triggered control schemes for heterogeneous linear multiagent systems.

The disturbance is common in many engineering control systems and should be considered in the control process [27]- [31]. The concept of the disturbance observer was presented by Nakao et al. [32] the first time. In [33], both the optimal consensus controller and disturbance observer were designed based on the H 2 performance index of each subsystem. Wang et al. [34] investigated the output consensus problem for higher-order nonlinear multiagent systems subject to mismatched disturbances. To the authors' best knowledge, there are few results about adaptive event-triggered control for multiagent systems with external disturbances based on the disturbance observer.

Motivated by the above discussion, this paper focuses on an event-triggered tracking control issue for the nonlinear multiagent systems with unknown disturbances. The main contributions are listed as follows.

1) Since the unknown disturbances widely exist in industrial applications, and may decrease, or even deteriorate the stability of considered systems, the observer can detect external disturbances effectively and eliminate the impact of disturbances in this paper. 2) Unlike [34], this paper considers an unknown nonlinear function in multiagent systems with unknown disturbances, which is a new challenge for the design of the disturbance observer. 3) A novel adaptive event-triggered control method is developed for nonstrict-feedback multiagent systems with unknown disturbances. Compared with timetriggered control [17], [33], [35], the communication bandwidth and resource are saved by reducing the controllers' update frequency. The organization of this paper is shown as follows. The graph theory, the system formulation, mathematical description of the radial basis function neural networks (RBF NNs), and disturbance observer design are stated in Section II. The event-triggered controller design and stability analysis are derived in Section III. A simulation example and conclusion are shown in Sections IV and V, respectively.

Notation: R n and R N×M stand for the n-dimensional and N × M-dimensional Euclidean space, respectively. 1 N means the N-dimensional identity matrix. λ max (A) and λ min (A) represent the matrix maximum eigenvalue and the minimum eigenvalue of A ∈ R N×N , respectively. col{•} stands for the column vector. |•| denotes the absolute value, and • refers to Euclidean norm of vectors or matrices. sup(•) stands for the supremacy. arg min{•} expresses the value of the variable that minimizes {•}.

div.head: A. Graph Theory
div.p: In this section, we introduce an interaction graph to express the information communication between agents. Consider a directed graph ζ = (V, E, A), where V = (1, . . . , N) means the node set, E ⊆ V × V is edge set, and A = [a i,j ] ∈ R N×N is the relevant adjacency matrix. An edge from node i to j is denoted as (V j , V i ) ∈ E. The set of neighbors is shown as N i = {V j |(V j , V i ) ∈ E, i = j}. For adjacency matrix A, if the information of node j can be received the node i, a i,j > 0, and otherwise a i,j = 0. The in-degree is defined as d i = j∈N i a i,j and D = diag(d 1 , . . . , d N ) is a diagonal matrix. The Laplacian matrix of ζ is L = (l i,j ) = D-A and L1 N = 0, where 1 N = col{1, 1, . . . , 1} ∈ R N×1 . The augmented graph is described as ζ = ( V, Ē) with V = (0, 1, . . . , N) and Ē ⊆ V × V, where 0 is called as a leader. Similarly, a i,0 > 0, if and only if the node i can receive the information from node 0 and a i,0 = 0 otherwise.

Lemma 1 [36]: The digraph ζ is said to have a spanning tree, if there is at least a directed path from the root to all other nodes. If denote B = diag(a 1,0 , . . . , a N,0 ), the node 0 is called the root of the spanning tree, then the matrix L + B is nonsingular.

div.head: B. System Formulation
div.p: The agent i can be represented by the following n-order nonstrict-feedback system:
div.formula: ẋi,m = x i,m+1 + f i,m (x i ) + d i,m (t) ẋi,n = u i + f i,n (x i ) + d i,n (t) y i = x i,1(1)
div.p: where m = 1, 2, . . . , n -1, x i = col{x i,1 , x i,2 , . . . , x i,n } ∈ R N is the state vector with i = 1, 2, . . . , N, f i,m (x i ) and f i,n (x i ) are unknown smooth nonlinear functions, the external disturbances d i,m and d i,n are unknown bounded functions, y i represents the output of agent i and u i is the controller to be designed later. The output signal of leader is y 0 , which is smooth.

div.head: C. RBF NNs
div.p: RBF NNs are introduced to estimate the nonlinear function f (Z) as follows:
div.formula: f (Z) = W T S(Z)
div.p: where S(Z) = [S 1 (Z), S 2 (Z), . . . , S k (Z)] T stands for the basis function vector with k being the number of RBF NN nodes, and
div.formula: W = [W 1 , W 2 , . . . , W k ] T ∈ R k is weights vector.
div.p: Then, there is an ideal constant weight vector W * such that the following equation holds:
div.formula: f (Z) = W * T S(Z) + δ(Z), ∀Z ∈ ⊂ R q .
div.p: We choose W * as follows:
div.formula: W * : = arg min W∈R k sup Z∈ f (Z) -W T S(Z)
div.p: where approximation error δ(Z) satisfies |δ(Z)| ≤ ε with ε > 0, and
In this paper, the following Gaussian basis function S i (Z) will be utilized:
div.formula: S i (Z) = exp - (Z -ι i ) T (Z -ι i ) ω 2 i (3
div.p: where
div.formula: ι i = [ι i1 , ι i2 , . . . , ι iq ]
div.p: T denotes the center of the receptive field and ω i stands for the width of the Gaussian function with i = 1, 2, . . . , k. Lemma 2 [37]:
div.formula: Let S xq = S 1 xq , S 2 xq , . . . , S k xq T with xq = [x 1 , . . . ,
div.p: x q ] T be the basis function vector of RBF NNs. Then for any positive integer p ≤ q, one has
div.formula: S xq 2 ≤ S xp 2 . (4

div.head: D. Disturbance Observer Design
div.p: First, RBF NN is employed to estimate the unknown nonlinear function f i,k (x i ) as follows:
div.formula: f i,k (x i ) = M * T i,k S i,k (x i ) + ϑ i,k (x i ), ∀x i ∈ x i where M * i,k is an ideal constant weight vector, S i,k (x i ) is Gaussian basis function, and ϑ i,k (x i ) is approximation error satisfying |ϑ i,k (x i )| ≤ ϑ i,k,0 with ϑ i,k,0 > 0.
div.p: The multiagent systems are rewritten as
div.formula: ẋi,m = x i,m+1 + M * T i,m S i,m (x i ) + ϑ i,m (x i ) + d i,m (t) ẋi,n = u i + M * T i,n S i,n (x i ) + ϑ i,n (x i ) + d i,n (t) y i = x i,1 .
div.p: Then, disturbance observer for system ( 5) is presented as follows:
div.formula: ẑi,k = λ i,k x i,k -P i,k Ṗi,k = x i,k+1 + ẑi,k + MT i,k S i,k (x i ) (6) for i = 1, 2, . . . , N, k = 1, 2, . . . , n, where λ i,k > 0 is a designed parameter, Mi,k is the estimation of M * i,k with Mi,k = M * i,k -Mi,k and x i,n+1 = u i . Furthermore, the disturbance estimation is derived as żi,k = λ i,k ẋi,k -Ṗi,k = λ i,k d i,k (t) -ẑi,k + MT i,k S i,k (x i ) + ϑ i,k (x i ) . The disturbance estimation error is governed by żi,k = -λ i,k zi,k + ḋi,k (t) -λ i,k MT i,k S i,k (x i ) + ϑ i,k (x i ) (7)
div.p: where zi,k = d i,k (t) -ẑi,k .

div.head: III. DISTRIBUTED CONSENSUS CONTROLLER
div.p: In this portion, we will handle the consensus tracking problem of multiagent systems by backstepping technique.
This paper aims to design a distributed controller such that the followers' outputs y i locate in a small area of the output of leader y 0 .
To facilitate deriving the control scheme, define the adaptive parameters as
where W * i,k is an ideal constant weight vector in RBF NNs and θi is the estimation of θ i with θi = θ i -θi .

Remark 1: In (8), i is the number of followers and k represents the number of NN nodes. It is clear that the adaptive parameters are only dependent on the number of followers, which reduces the computation burden.
Define the following new variables:
div.formula: e i,1 = j∈N i a i,j y i -y j + a i,0 (y i -y 0 ) e i,ξ = x i,ξ -α i,ξ -1(9)
div.p: where i = 1, . . . , N, ξ = 2, . . . , n, e i,1 is the synchronization error, α i,ξ -1 is the virtual variable, and the pinning gain a i,0 ≥ 0. Lemma 3 [38]:
div.formula: Define e 1 = col{e 1,1 , e 2,1 , . . . , e N,1 }, y = col{y 1 , y 2 , . . . , y N }, ȳ0 = 1 N ⊗ y 0 , then y -ȳ0 ≤ e 1 σ (L + B) (10)
div.p: holds, where σ (L + B) is the minimum singular value of L + B.

div.p: Step n: The derivative of the error e i,n is expressed as
div.formula: ėi,n = u i + f i,n (x i ) + d i,n (t) -αi,n-1(33)

div.formula: αi,n-1 = n-1 β=1 ∂α i,n-1 ∂x i,β x i,β+1 + f i,β (x i ) + d i,β (t) + n-1 β=1 j∈N i ∂α i,n-1 ∂x j,β x j,β+1 + f j,β (x j ) + d j,β (t) + ∂α i,n-1 ∂ θi θi + n-1 β=0 ∂α i,n-1 ∂y (β) 0 y (β+1) 0 + n-1 β=1 ∂α i,n-1 ∂ ẑi,β λ i,β zi,β + MT i,β S i,β (x i ) + ϑ i,β (x i ) + n-1 β=1 j∈N i ∂α i,n-1 ∂ ẑj,β λ j,β × zj,β + MT j,β S j,β (x j ) + ϑ j,β (x j ) .
div.p: The Lyapunov function is selected as

div.p: Then, the following formula can be derived:

div.p: The adaptive controller is designed as

div.p: The event triggering mechanism is defined as
div.formula: u i (t) = ω i (t k ), ∀t ∈ t k , t k+1 ) (44
div.p: where the event-triggered error i (t) = ω i (t)u i (t). The controller update time is defined as t k , k ∈ Z + , and designed parameters i , 0
div.formula: < i < 1, m i > 0, and mi > [(m i )/(1 -i )] are positive. When time t ∈ [t k , t k+1
div.p: ), the controller holds as ω i (t k ). When (45) is triggered, the control signal will be updated and it is marked as u i (t k+1 ). Thus, there exist two continuous time-varying parameters i,1 (t) and i,2 (t) such that
div.formula: ω i (t) = (1 + i,1 (t) i )u i (t) + i,1 (t)m i , where | i,1 (t)| ≤ 1 and | i,2 (t)| ≤ 1. Therefore, one gets u i (t) = [(ω i (t) - i,2 (t)m i )/(1 + i,1 (t) i )].
div.p: Similar to [36], the following inequality holds:
div.formula: Vi,n ≤ - n β=1 k i,β e 2 i,β -i,n mi + e i,n m i 1 -i + 0.557 i + ρ i γ i θi θi + n-1 β=1 (n -β)c i z2 i,β + n-1 β=1 j∈N i (n -β)r i z2 j,β + n β=1 zi,β -λ i,β zi,β + ḋi,β + d i + a i,0 + 1 2 z2 i,1 + j∈N i a i,j 2 z2 j,1 + n β=2 z2 i,β + n β=1 p 2 i,β 2 + ε 2 i,β 2 + n β=1 l i,β η i,β MT i,β Mi,β + n β=1 λ 2 i,β ϑ 2 i,β,0 2 .
div.p: Remark 2: The controller update time t k is a monotonically increasing subsequence with t 0 = 0. The last held controller vector at zero-order hold is undated at each t = t k for k ∈ Z + .

Theorem 1: The multiagent systems (1) and the event-triggered distributed controller (44) are taken into account. Then, it can be realized that all the signals are bounded, the tracking errors arrive at a bounded compact set of the origin, and the interexecution intervals {t k+1t k } are lower bounded by a nonzero time t * > 0.
Proof: The Lyapunov function is designed as
div.formula: V = N i=1 V i,n . (46

div.p: Let

IEEE TRANSACTIONS ON CYBERNETICS Set μ = min 1≤i≤N ⎧ ⎨ ⎩ n β=1 2k i,β , ρ i , 2 λ i,1 -(n -1)c i j∈N i (n -1)r j - d i + a i,0 + 1 2 - j∈N i a j,i 2 -λ i,0 , 2 ⎛ ⎝ λ i,h -(n -h)c i - j∈N i (n -h)r j -1 -λ i,0 ⎞ ⎠ , 2 λ i,n -1 -λ i,0 , l i,β ⎫ ⎬ ⎭ π = N i=1 0.557 i + N i=1 ρ i 2γ i θ 2 i + N i=1 n β=1 p 2 i,β 2 + ε 2 i,β 2 + N i=1 n β=1 l i,β 2η i,β M * T i,β M * i,β
div.p: where h = 2, . . . , n -1. Thus, (47) can be rewritten as
div.formula: V(t) ≤ -μV(t) + π.
div.p: Further, we can obtain all signals are bounded. Then, one gets
div.formula: 1 2 e 2 i,1 ≤ V ≤ e -μt V(0) + π μ 1 -e -μt .
div.p: Based on Lemma 3, one has
div.formula: lim t→∞ y -ȳ0 ≤ 1 σ (L + B) 2π μ . (48
div.p: The inequality [1/(σ (L + B))] √ (2π/μ) ≤ κ holds for any κ by selecting the designed parameters based on the definitions of π and μ, which further implies lim t→∞ y -ȳ0 ≤ κ, that is, the tracking errors can maintain in a small range of the origin.
Motivated by [39], one has
div.formula: d dt | i (t)| = d dt ( i (t) × i (t)) 1 2 = sign( i (t)) ˙ i | ωi(49)
div.p: From ( 41), we can get
div.formula: ωi (t) = -(1 + i ) ⎛ ⎝ αi,n tanh e i,n α i,n i + α i,n × ėi,n α i,n i + e i,n αi,n i cosh 2 e i,n α i,n i + m2 i ėi,n i cosh 2 e i,n mi i ⎞ ⎠ .
div.p: Since all the signals are globally bounded, | ωi (t)| ≤ κ can be obtained where κ is a positive parameter. Based on ( 44) and (45), i (t k ) = 0 and lim t→t k+1 i (t) = i |u i (t)| + m i hold. Then, the lower bound of the interexecution time t * satisfies t * ≥ [( i |u i (t)| + m i )/κ] for ∀t ∈ [t k , t k+1 ), i.e., the Zeno behavior can be effectively eliminated.

Remark 3: In [40], the transmission events are dependent on the error, the latest transmitted states, and the adjustable threshold. In (45), the transmission events rely on the error, the latest transmitted controller, and the adjustable threshold. Further, disparate event-triggered mechanisms may result in designing different controllers. This clearly indicates the necessity of designing the controller and the event triggering mechanism at the same time.

In the next section, a numerical example is given and the control objective can be realized. Furthermore, our theoretical research can also be applied to practical systems, such as the robot manipulator in [41] and vehicle motion systems. However, quadrotors and two-wheeled mobile robots in [42]- [44] will be studied in our further research.

div.head: IV. SIMULATION RESULTS
div.p: Multiagent systems with four follower agents and one leader agent are described in Fig. 1 in this section. Each agent's dynamic is modeled as
div.formula: x i,1 = x i,2 + x 2 i,1 sin x i,2 + d i,1 x i,2 = u i + sin x i,1 x i,2 + d i,2 y i = x i,1 , i = 1, . . . , 4
div.p: where d i,1 = x i,1 sin(x i,2 ) cos(t), d i,2 = 1 + x i,1 x i,2 sin 2 (t). The leader's signal is y 0 = 0.5 sin(t). According to Fig. 1, the adjacency matrix A and the Laplacian matrix L are as follows, respectively, the leader adjacency matrix is B = diag(1, 0, 1, 0). The correlative design parameters are chosen as λ i,1 = λ i,2 = 400.5, γ i = 4.9, k i,1 = 108, k i,2 = 65, ρ i = 0.6, p i,1 = p i,2 = 10.9, times. They also have shown the advantage of cost saving for the event-triggered controllers. The triggered times of the event-triggered controller are 497, 719, 462, and 699, respectively.

div.head: V. CONCLUSION
div.p: The event-triggered control problem of nonlinear multiagent systems with unknown disturbances has been studied in this paper. To handle the unknown disturbances, a disturbance observer has been proposed. A distributed event-triggered controller has been designed to save the network transmission resources. Furthermore, a part of the estimation parameters only dependent on the number of the followers have been raised to reduce the computation burden. Finally, the effectiveness of the proposed protocol has been testified by simulation results. In the future, we will study the consensus problem under the time-varying topology or switching topology. On the other hand, we are also interested in improving the anti-interference ability of the multiagent systems.

div.p: This work was supported in part by the National Natural Science Foundation of China under Grant 61703051, Grant 61622302, and Grant 61522303, in part by the Department of Education of Guangdong Province under Grant 2017KZDXM027, in part by the Department of Education of Liaoning Province under Grant LZ2017001, in part by the Innovative Research Team Program of Guangdong Province Science Foundation under Grant 2018B030312006, and in part by the Science and Technology Planning Project of Guangdong Province under Grant 2017B010116006. This paper was recommended by Associate Editor S.-F. Su.
Yanhui Zhang received the B.S. degree in mathematics and applied mathematics from Bohai University, Jinzhou, China, in 2016, where she is currently pursuing the M.S. degree in applied mathematics.
Her current research interests include adaptive control, multi-agent systems, and nonlinear systems.
